comments.commentBody: There's actually a giant divergence, not a contradiction.  As Thomas Piketty showed, the return on capital in the economy, measured by markets such as stocks and bonds, exceeds the return on labor, i.e. income from working, which drives consumption.  These measurements are simply a reflection of the inequality effect.  Of course it can't go on forever, but as long as companies can cut costs to drive earnings, especially from overseas markets, this is the result.  Eventually, the house of cards folds.  No one can predict when.

Exactly.  Especially galling since it was a far more legitimate one, with a turnout that was one of the highest in decades, and a win-margin that was also one of the biggest in many presidential cycles.  For all their talk now about 'respecting the voters', they gave none when the shoe was on the other foot.  (Which gives me a sort of smug satisfaction when I see Republican heads pop off about Obama's 'gall')

I lived in Florissant growing up.  It's suburbia and there are no alleys.   Taylor was murdered in north St Louis as was Al-Hamid. Neither was shot by the police. Do you expect the New York Times to cover every local crime story in the US?

On average, 34 people are murdered each day in the US. Are you expecting the Times to devote an article to each instance?

Incidentally, both of the boys whose deaths you cite here were white. And they were victims of crime; they were not shot by the police.

It is difficult for outsiders to understand the make up of St Louis.  There is the City of St Louis.  There is "downtown."  Then there is the county of St Louis which is made up of many smaller municipalities.  Ferguson and Florissant are two cities within their own right that are a part of the County of St Louis.  Then there is  "North St Louis."  People use this term correctly to refer to the northern part of the City of St Louis that is primarily inhabited by African Americans.  People incorrectly use the term to refer to the northern part of St Louis County where the cities of Ferguson and Florissant are located.   This is an area where many African Americans have moved from North St Louis (City) to improve their lives.

Steven Taylor, 18, was shot dead in a Florrisant alley in the middle of the afternoon last week. Zachary al-Hamid was just16 when he was gunned down just miles from where Michael Brown died. That murder also occurred last week. One week - and there were others. Yet, there are no protest marches, no outcry, and a search of The New York Times finds not a mention of their names.

Gerrymandering along with ID laws will make that impossible. The Police know that people have to get on with their lives, sooner or later. The press move on to the next fire and nothing ever happens. The overseeing class has become really good at this.

Calhoon, you know nothing of the US or history or facts about Ferguson.  But, I can tell you that Ferguson government demographics have nothing to do with Gerrymandering, it has to do with a voter turnout that in the election of 2012 was 12%.  You're sentiments are nonsense.
Exercise your rights register your rights and kick the scoundrels out of office.That would be the best legacy for Mr. Brown.

We've put a man on the moon. We've used skycrane to lower a 1 ton rover onto the Martian surface. And yet we haven't been able to come up with a non-lethal way for our police to rapidly stop a threat and prevent accidents like this one from happening. Unbelievable.

Arun: Schuck is making the case that, while it may be legal to impeach the president, it would be a bad decision. Essentially, he argues that this is a political decision, because the Constitution is vague on grounds for impeachment. "High crimes" sounds like big things; "misdemeanors," like little things.

But Article 2, section 4 reads: "The President, Vice President and all civil Officers of the United States, shall be removed from Office on Impeachment for, and Conviction of, Treason, Bribery, or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors." Here it would seem that the adjective "high" Modifies both "Crimes" and "Misdemeanors." But I'm no lawyer, just a poet.

Schuck is a lawyer, and I tend to agree with his argument -- but he is not arguing that one should impeach this president, only that it is legal to do so.

It will be terrible for the country if they waste the next two years punishing Obama with impeachment and law suits, but it will insure a democratic win in 2016, as everyone will be fed up with their lack of positive results.
Let our people go! What are you afraid of? That we might be more successful than you think we could be? I can just see all those corporations moving to the United States of the Sunbelt now.

Bah, we didn't impeach a President for authorizing torture; we're going to impeach a President for keeping families together?

You and your ilk who think it is legal to impeach the President, go join the Confederacy and stop pretending to be a citizen of the United States.
NYPD is getting much better at handling the PR of all of these accidental murders. Practice makes perfect.

We are so sad and upset over this man we don't know what to think. We're grieving as if he were our own. We are afraid for these young black men, who don't appear to do anything and their only crime is being persons of color. There is something seriously wrong with this picture.

I nominate this Ernest Velasquez statement as comment of the day for its eloquence and historical accuracy! It should be writ large on the front page of the NYT for every reader to absorb. Next, slip a copy under the door of the House Speaker; also, into the mailbox of the soon to be Senate  majority leader, McConnell.

The last part of your comment begs some questions. For one, if the U.S. Southwest was still part of Mexico, would it be a place where Mexicans wanted to live? Also, I live in North Carolina. Did that border cross you?

You're basically arguing that Mexicans have the right to live anywhere in the United States without permission. Does that also apply to Central Americans? To Filipinos? Or is it just Mexicans who don't have to obey U.S. law?

EV What you are saying, essentially is that the US does not have sovereignty over that Southwest and that a resident of Mexico City has the same right to be in Los Angeles as a resident of Chicago. For those of us who believe that the US has sovereignty over the Southwest, your point is an argument against Obama's action.
Would add that certain factions of La Gaza share your viewpoint.

JD

My great-great-great-grand father was born in San Jose California in 1821. My grand father was born in the Arizona territory in 1872 and my father was also born in the Arizona territory in 1911.
My grand father grand mother and some of the adult children, including my father moved to Chihuahua Mexico during the depression of 1917. Thus my brother and two sisters were born in Mexico. Based on the then existing immigration laws, my brother and I [males] were granted natural born citizenship at birth.
In the early 50's we moved to Los Angeles where I went to school and upon graduation from High School, I joined the US Air Force and served four year in Germany which coincided with the building of The Berlin wall and the Cuban Missiles crisis. Just to make it clear, I love my country and served to protect our great democracy. My two favorite president: Jefferson and Lincoln.

Now to my point on current immigration.
First: We Mexicans are not immigrants, we were conquered and lost the Southwest territory in the Mexican/American War of 1850 that included California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Arizona New Mexico and Texas.
Second: Many of us have the blood of Indigenous and European [Spanish] conquistadors running through our veins.
Third: we were here first, so stop calling us immigrants. As the great union leader Dolores Huerta has stated " we did not cross the border, the border crossed us.

@Emmet Martin

Agreed in terms of the danger of walking, driving etc. while black. I do hold White/Asian/Hispanic Americans accountable for that. But to be fair, and I know this isn't exactly PC, there is good cause for a lot of the fear. If one is walking down the street at night and a group of young black dudes in hoodies comes along, tell me that you don't have some concern. So I'd say that while there is much work to do in the US in terms of eliminating our stereotypical reactions to black males. there is likewise much work to do for black males to avoid reasons to add to these stereotypes. Both sides need to engage in this work in order to make headway.

The Police departments  in America as constituted pose a clear and present  danger to poor Black Americans and specifically to Black males and to a less extent to more affluent black Americans.  Its clear that irrespective of the neutral behavior that you can become a victim of a fatal police encounter, if walking, talking or driving while black, as recent events have shown .  The perception of Black Males are such, walking down the stairs can be suspicious activity. When Black males walk through cities and Suburbs of America's women hold their bags, or lock the Car doors as black males approaches, as president Obama have acknowledged these kind incidents are part of his personal experiences .   If America does not own up to the truth, of how it views and treats it's Black citizens the problem will persist.  One of the rules of Gun ownership is, you never point and/or put your finger on the trigger unless u are willing to kill what you are aiming at, so that would negates the accidental  discharge excuse.  Its ironic that the tenants were forced are forced to walk down these darken stairs alone and without an armed partner or their finger on the trigger of an  automatic weapon. But Mr.Liang was so afraid that he pointed and discharged his weapon at Mr.Gurley without a readily discernable reason. At a minimum Mr.Liang Career in Law enforcement is History.  America has to fight its nascent views of its own black citizens.

Anybody here ever walk down a dark staircase in the Housing Projects? I think that would be a bit scary. The cop needs to be investigated. He hit the guy in the chest after all. Sounds like criminally negligent homicide to me.

Some pistols have separate thumb operated safeties but teaching proper use is like an automatic vs a manual transmission in a car. They do not automatically make it safer as sometimes people forget to thumb them off when they need to shoot or rely on it when it is accidentally off causing discharges. Keep your finger off the trigger until you want to fire the pistol is simple and effective training.

If the officer had his gun out he felt it was necessary and I have no reason to question that decision. The issue is his gun handling. I am certain he had no intention of shooting a completely innocent unknown person.

What money is spent supporting undocumented immigrants? Please give us some documentation. How about some facts, not just your personal opinion.

So suppose you sent all the motel maids back to their home countries, the dishwashers, the lettuce, citrus fruit, and other agricultural seasonal laborers, just go out and round them all up. Do you think all those out of work white collar workers will be lining up to harvest broccoli at daybreak in the Salinas Valley, then move on to pick grapes in the Napa Valley, then on to Washington to pick apples?

Well, do you? You think you are spending money now, just wait until you have to buy your vegetables and fruit from some other country, and if you want it fresh, maybe you will have it flown in?

Do you think the dishwasher and busboys at your favorite restaurant get union wages. How about when you stay at a motel, what are you willing to pay a night?
Okay, I Googled the mayor. I still would rather die than live in a place where people have to prove something by bringing guns everywhere.

The parts of Buddy Flanigan they fished out of the East River won't hold together for an open casket funeral. Still, his mother will gather some of the old maids of Banner Street to cry about it, as well as some of us jetsam he hung around to put on suits and mourn this dried out piece of flotsam.

He was a good kid, we'll say, and we’ll ask how it happened. We’ll know perfectly well how it happened.

Public opinion seems pretty set on letting this dead dog lie. The good kid story works just fine for his mother, and the pictures they snapped right after they pulled him out work just fine for the Post. But Buddy didn't want to be a good kid from Brooklyn, and he didn't want people in suits to say it, either. He wanted to be tough.

Jack pried open his eyes. He tasted salt on his chops and grit in his teeth. The banging in his skull was more than last night’s bourbon doing its victory dance.

Hard heels on old wood hammered a machine gun staccato between his eyes. How he ended up under the Coney boardwalk he had no clue.

Shading his eyes with crooked fingers, Jack emerged from the urban cave. He started walking toward Bed Stuy, Flatbush Avenue, Banner Street, his turf. Where he ruled the roost, like rats ruled garbage.

He searched his pockets for a butt and found zilch except for a bright yellow scarf smeared with blood-red lipstick. Looks like everyone had a swell time on his account last night.

Jack buried his mug in the scarf and tried to remember something, anything, but got nothing but a snout full of cheap perfume.

In the diner, he always sat at the booth in the back. When he was a kid, his uncle told him it was where the neighborhood gangsters used to sit because if the cops showed up, they were out through the kitchen and into the alley before anyone knew what was happening. Now he sat there because he could watch the girls come in, working girls mostly but sometimes real classy broads who looked like they should be nuzzled up to a Rockefeller in a Manhattan penthouse. He liked to buy them a cup of coffee and offer them a smoke and see if he could make them smile. Mostly they didn’t, except for that special smile a girl uses on a man who hasn’t got a shot in hell, but she wants to make him feel okay about it. He always felt okay about it.

Until she walked in.

At the other end of the counter it was crowded, and at this end Whiskers sat alone, licking the cream off the rim of his milkshake. Whiskers couldn't taste the sweetness. Honestly, he thought, you can't taste the sweetness in any part of life, kitty tongues didn't even have the taste buds for that. And then, as some cats do every once in a while, Whiskers toyed with the idea of offing himself.
You could do it tonight, he thought, and that was when the girl walked in. Whiskers recognized her from the magazines. A washed up pop star who used to go by the name of Katy Perry. She had the kind of curves that would make most men so crazy they'd end up in a bathtub, holding a razor and watching the blood leak out of their veins.
Whiskers didn't care about the curves, he only saw the dark circles that framed her lonely eyes.

Hey, this is the summer of 1950. The Big Deuce has been over for five years. A new war is starting in some place called Korea. But, I'm not planning to go there and plunk a M-1 Garand and freeze my tail off. Nope. I might end up in a Wooden Kimono.

A little chunk of Brooklyn is going to be mine. It starts tonight with this bar I'm in on Banner Street. It's a scruffy joint, infested with hookers, hard guys, and grifters with a nearby Bridge to sell.

The Navy Yard no longer pumps out Battleships and Leavittowns are in. So what? Lots of jack is still Downtown, if you've got the bulge. And I do. But the bim I'm dizzy for is late. I'm ready to explode. She's the bait. Nice gams and a great rack! Where the hell is Princess? Our sucker is all ribbed up!

The day they slept in the same bed, the challenge was on. Having fathers that both drank alcohol, often fought, and eventually sent both into the police office did not exactly make both families friends. The girl’s ex-boyfriend, Sven, was one of the strongest gangster in Brooklyn, and he was definitely jealous. It had been ten months since they had been together, but a couple days ago, Sven’s gang persuaded the cops to gang up with them...and their drunk parents were mindlessly supporting them. The couple had not left home for three days, and food was running low. But it didn’t matter anymore, because the house is burnt down. They had to move out of Brooklyn, as a matter of fact, they had to move out of New York.

The ballroom was teeming with youth. Exuberant, street-smart kids were dressed to the nines looking for their ticket out of “Shantytown” as they not-so-affectionately called Trenton Market, Brooklyn’s darkest corner and their home.

The girls in fancy heels and sheer blouses coupled up with guys who pumped iron and had enough shiny stuff in their hair to grease a whole assembly line of cars. Already veterans of heavy drinking and hard partying, all were resolutely sober waiting for their names to be called.

In Shantytown, life was a shadow of what it could be. The ballroom was an escape from the darkness, offering a chance to be someone different, someone better.

Darlene entered the cramped apartment. Hours had passed since she'd fired the gun point blank at Teddy's chest, but still it burned red hot in her hand. She placed it on the chipped formica table where it found companionship in the stinking mess of overflowing ashtrays, worthless stubs from the races, and drained fifths of cheap bourbon.

She untied the yellow satin halter top, the shameless scrap of fabric now stained with blood and sweat, and let it slip to the floor along with her skirt and panties.

Footsteps ran up the stairs and her forgetful heart leapt with hope at Teddy's return, only to break as she remembered... The midnight street, his cruel slap. Bang! Her last glimpse of him through streaming tears. His face twisting from rage to fear as crimson tendrils of blood spilled between his fingers.

A tough kid from Brooklyn was dead.
This is the best snippet of pulp fiction I've read so far. Harris is obviously very capable and should win this contest.

She was back at the doc's. Go figure. Hot dame, gams for days, always with the Croaker. Yeah, she had a smile I felt in my hip pocket, but the light in those baby blues was fading. Her old man wasn't knockin' her around. He lived for that dame, but didn't know her secret.

I couldn't drive the Caddy. She'd see it a mile away. So I pounded the grimy streets till my dogs were barking. Never liked cabbies. Always running their yap. All I wanted in this filthy city were answers.

The walk cleared my head, but the past crept back in. She did a number on me. I got it bad for this dame. You knew that, but what you don't know is, I was the only woman she ever loved. She's the only woman I ever killed for. The gun is my purse is still warm, sister.

We followed the car chase as closely as we could. Later, the headlines would read, "Cops Killed by Femme Fatale," "Brooklyn's Bonnie and Clyde on the Run," "Murder-Suicide by the Docks."

Before all that, Marilyn and I were engaged to be married. I remember I asked my little brother Tommy before we started going together, because I knew how he'd gotten detention for putting peanut butter in her hair and how he always kicked her around on the playground, taunting, "Marilyn, Marilyn, nobody likes you." At home, I'd teased him about liking her.

We were engaged when I became the lone kid from Banner Street to go off to college, and Tommy dropped out. It was then that she started hanging around him. I wrote her letters, phoned as often as I could, but come Christmas, I found them pressed against the shaded wall of my parents’ house.
